properties.name: Baltasound, Unst
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyBy 2002, only Baltasound post office remained on Unst, claiming the title of Britain\'s most northerly. We wrote: \'The next nearest post office is a ferry trip away. Valerie Johnson, Baltasound\'s sub-postmistress, fears for the future. Valerie, 36, married with three children, says: \'I only survive as a business because my husband is self-employed. \'A large part of my job is equivalent to a social service. I must stay open for the community - it\'s not about making money. \'If the post office closed, there would be nowhere left on the island to provide postal and benefit needs. Elderly people would be forced to catch a ferry to another island to pick up their pensions - an appalling state of affairs.\' Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby Share your stories of post offices in the Shetlands. Click on Add quick comment below.

properties.name: Blaenavon Industrial Landscape
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyReporter Toby Walne travelled on a motorbike from John o\'Groats to Land\'s End to report on Government plans that spelled doom for hundreds of the 17,500 post offices branches. On day six he reached Blaenavon, known as the Birthplace of Steel. It is believed that the world\'s first steelworks opened here in 1878. Postmaster Ken Booth, 63, (pictured) has only one counter in his town centre post office. To make ends meet, he has opened a bakery in the branch. He says: \'Between the wars this town was thriving. There were about 17,500 people involved in or linked to the mining industry. Since the decline of the coal industry, Blaenavon has struggled to survive, but the town has refused to die and community services such as ours have been well supported.\' Ken now believes the Government is introducing underhand measures that could force him to close despite widespread customer support. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Cambridge
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyCB2 3AA, EnglandCambridge is lauded as a centre of academic excellence, but it also possesses an unenviable reputation - as home to the post office with the longest queues. The branch in question is the main post office situated on St Andrew\'s Street. Earlier this year, a Postwatch undercover survey labelled it the country\'s worst offender for queues, with a customer waiting time of up to 21 minutes. Unfortunately, nine months on, despite being admonished by Postwatch, the queues do not seem to be shrinking. Last week, when Financial Mail visited, only three of the main 13 counters were open despite it being lunchtime and more than two-dozen people waiting - though customers say it can get far busier. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Castle Douglas
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyCounter assistant Gordon McCutcheon reverses his car up to the rear of the post office in the isolated village of Castle Douglas near Solway Firth. He picks up two bags, puts them into the boot and drives away. It is 8.30am and Gordon\'s \'post office\' is on the move. First stop is Haugh of Urr, three-and-a-half miles away. This 200-strong community lost its post office two years ago - until Gordon\'s flatpack post office arrived. By paying the general store in Haugh of Urr to use a counter for eight hours a week, the community has maintained its post office. Farmer Lindsay Callender, 36, (pictured) visiting with son Jack, 4, to post parcels, says: \'This is more than just a post office service - it is a community lifeline.\' Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Chesham Bois
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyHP5 1DE, EnglandWalking past the cluster of shops in the attractive village of Chesham Bois, nothing appears amiss. It is a quiet and pleasant spot with a steady stream of customers arriving by car to shop. Yet despite an upmarket feel to the parade in Bois Lane, which includes a home furnishings shop with coffee bar and a butcher\'s shop, there is a lack of grassroots services. Luxury goods and cappuccinos are all well and good, say locals, but there is nowhere for basic groceries, postage or banking needs. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Chobham
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneySurrey, EnglandWar veteran Pat Handley (pictured) is proud to pledge his support to our Save Our Post Offices campaign. The 84-year-old widower was among a 1,000-strong army of protesters who descended on Westminster in London demanding Government action to halt post office branch closures. The demonstration followed comments by Trade and Industry Secretary Alistair Darling that the current network of branches is unsustainable. Pat, of Chobham, Surrey, was in Burma as an RAF engineer during the Second World War, after which he worked as a coal truck driver and farm labourer. Gwen, his wife of 50 years, died eight years ago. He is still close to his daughter Sharon, 50, who lives in Kent. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Colinton
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyEH14 1DJTrade and Industry Secretary Alistair Darling\'s announcement in Parliament of a further culling of the Post Office network spells the end for thousands of branches. Toby Walne visited Darling\'s Edinburgh South West constituency - home to a dozen post offices - to gauge reactions. The village of Colinton, sitting next to the Water of Leith river, has long been engulfed by Edinburgh suburbia. Yet it still maintains a strong sense of identity in the 4,000-strong community. At its heart, surrounded by half a dozen shops, is the post office. Although a bustling branch, it urgently needs a revamp. But subpostmaster Tom Pate, 58, fears that Thursday\'s announcement means this refurbishment will never happen. Tom, who runs the branch with his sister, Moira, 56, explains: \'We want to invest, but with uncertainty over our future we dare not spend money - if things carry on as they are we will be out of business.\' Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Crewe
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyCW1 5EQ, EnglandRoyal Mail launched a competition three months ago to find the country\'s favourite post offices. Embarrassingly, not long after, the Government said its support of the 14,300-strong network was unsustainable and that two-thirds could be axed. Last Thursday, behind closed doors, GMTV presenter Lorraine Kelly and Royal Mail \'unveiled\' the competition winners. Financial Mail on Sunday reporters visited the winning post offices to get reaction from postmasters and postmistresses and their customers. Overall winner: Running a post office is in Alan Green\'s blood. His grandfather, William Green, opened the doors of the family\'s sub-post office in Crewe, Cheshire, almost 50 years ago. And Alan\'s father, Neville, took over in 1977. Thirteen years ago, the post office moved a couple of hundred yards to its current location in Hungerford Road on the town\'s eastern edge. Neville and his wife, Margaret, ran the business until Alan took over ten years ago. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Cromarty
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyIV11 8UYTony Blair was presented with an early leaving present last week - but one he did not particularly welcome. On Monday, Financial Mail knocked on the door of 10 Downing Street to present more than 10,000 pledges of support for our Save Our Post Offices campaign. Martha Drysdale, 54, was among those to back the campaign. She completed a coupon when we recently visited Cromarty post office in the Highlands. Martha, who suffers from osteoporosis and uses crutches to walk, explains: \'Our post office is far more than just a service - it is a community lifeline. How are elderly and disabled people going to survive without a local post office branch? It is shameful that the Government wants to scrap a vital community service to make a profit.\' Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Dulverton
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyThe post office here in Brompton Regis, near Dulverton, Somerset is run by Pete & Jenny Stringer. Our village is about 5 miles from Dulverton, and therefore our shop and post office is essential to our community. We have a weekly bus service which is driven by volunteer drivers, so if the shop closes, it will be difficult for older villagers and people without cars to exist. If the post office closes, so would the shop, as one is reliant on the other to be a viable proposition. I hope you are successful in what you are doing for the post offices. Victor Little

properties.name: End of the road
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyReporter Toby Walne (pictured) travelled on a motorbike from John o\'Groats to Land\'s End to report on the impact of the Government\'s plans to scrap benefits books, a move that threatened the livelihoods of the thousands of people who run small post offices. After eight days he reached the end of the road and met Colin Usher, postmaster at the wonderfully named First & Last post office of Sennen and Land\'s End. Colin says: \'The Post Office appears to have made a real hash of promoting the changes. Banks have been quick off the mark publicising the opportunity to have benefits paid direct into accounts. But advertising for the Post Office card account, on which we will depend for revenue, has only recently started. It\'s a case of too little, too late.\' Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Frimley
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyPeter writes: Please add Farm Road, Warren Estate , Frimley, Surrey to your list. We have been using this Post Office ever since we moved here over 30 years ago. The current postmaster is so helpful and friendly and his wife helps out while his brother and his wife run the shop. My wife uses the Post Office to collect her pension - she is 93. Our nearest is in Frimley High St which involves trying to find somewhere to park and then queue. Camberley Main Office is even worse. Please do no let this Government get away with these closures.

properties.name: Galmpton
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyTQ5 0NH, EnglandThe quiet Devon village of Galmpton near Brixham is an unlikely setting for a revolution. But it is here that subpostmaster Gary Deare, 47, believes he has discovered a formula to transform the gloomy prospects of many threatened branches - with up to 3,000 facing the axe in the latest cull. Sick of Government meddling, he has embraced the ideas of his local community to create a post office branch that is thriving against the odds. There is nothing to make the old-fashioned Galleon Stores & Galmpton Post Office stand out - other than a fresh lick of white paint. Across the road is a family butcher and a hairdresser, the only other shops that serve this 1,200-strong community on the banks of the River Dart. But step inside and former bank manager Gary has revamped the interior, creating an innovative \'express post office\' service and a shop selling organic produce. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Hullbridge, Essex
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyJune Livemore (pictured) struggles to control her emotions as she contemplates the plight of her post office. For the past 26 years, the sub postmistress has served the 5,000 people of Hullbridge, which sits alongside the River Crouch just a few miles from the Essex coast. But since the axeing of benefit books four years ago and then a relocation to the back of a One Stop convenience store, the post office has struggled to survive. June, 65, says: \'I love serving the community, but my husband Derek recently retired and maybe I will soon too. But it will be hard to find a buyer for the branch. I am earning less money now than I was five years ago. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Isle of Wight
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyPO31 7BS, EnglandThey are a belligerent bunch on the Isle of Wight. Faced with a Government that seems determined to smash Britain\'s post office network, the islanders have fought back by issuing a \'unilateral declaration of independence\', calling for their post offices to be removed from Royal Mail control. And there is good reason to fight. The island has 52 branches serving 120,000 people, which is one for every 2,308 residents and almost double the national average. But that does not include the 2.6m \'grockles\' - tourists - who holiday on the island every year and often use the post office network. Yet the Government is poised to destroy this thriving network, allowing the closure of 35 branches, leaving only 17 post offices by 2010. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: John O'Groats
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyIn 2003, Reporter Toby Walne and photographer George Jaworskyj travelled 2,000 miles on a motorbike from John O\'Groats to Land\'s End to report on the impact of the Government\'s plans to scrap benefits books, a move that threatened the livelihoods of the thousands of people who run small post offices. Day 1: There is a warm welcome from postmistress Fiona Harper. She voices her support for Financial Mail\'s campaign to save local post offices and echoes the sentiments of people in branches throughout Britain. \'The Post Office\'s plan is being done with little or no consultation and all my customers are extremely upset about it,\' she says. Fiona wishes us a safe journey and we head 40 miles south... to Latheron. Sub-postmistress Lorna Gunn (pictured) admits she is fearful about the Post Office\'s plans. \'Over the years I have seen the gradual erosion of our community, with shops, schools and churches in the village closing down. I understand the Post Office\'s need to make money, but I think the amount of goodwill that will be lost is too high a price.\' Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Keighley
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyI live in a lovely village, Oxenhope, in Bronte country. Our village PO is under threat of closure. This would be a disaster for the village as most of the village stores have gone apart from the Co-op. I hope something can be done to prevent this from happening. Peter Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Kettlewell
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyBD23 5QUA remarkable success story has unfolded deep in the countryside - a new post office has started life. It is all the more astonishing when set against the background of more than 4,000 branch closures in five years. Nationally, the network is now down to 14,908 post offices with 8,100 of them in rural areas. More than 1,000 village post offices are among the casualties of the past five years. The new outlet is tucked away in a youth hostel at Kettlewell, a picturesque village in the Yorkshire Dales that was the setting for the hit film Calendar Girls, starring Julie Walters and Helen Mirren. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Land's End
properties.description: Posted by Thisismoney

properties.name: Langport
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyMy Local Post Office is Long Sutton, Langport, Somerset. Our village is approx 3 miles from the two nearest small towns and we are worried that the axe could fall on us on the basis that subjectively, they are not far away But 40% of the population are pensioners, many without transport and a there is only a minimal bus service to one of the towns. bjmjmeaden

properties.name: Lindfield
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyRH16 2HG, EnglandDame Vera Lynn (pictured), who was known as The Forces\' Sweetheart during the Second World War, is lending her voice to Financial Mail\'s Save Our Post Offices campaign. The 89-year-old singer, who famously raised the nation\'s morale with rousing songs including We\'ll Meet Again, regularly uses her local post office in Lindfield, West Sussex, and is furious with the Government over its threat to axe the Post Office card account. She believes that many elderly people will be abandoned if they have no transport and cannot easily get to their local bank and fears that community values may die. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Longborough, Gloucs
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyI live in the village of Longborough, Gloucestershire. Like many rural Post Offices, it provides a vital social service. If someone does not turn up for their pension the Post-Master Martin Gunson will either phone or call to see that they are ok. Dave Bates

properties.name: Maesbury Marsh
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneySY10 8JBDeep in rural Shropshire along a quiet stretch of canal sits a shiny new post office on the edge of the hamlet of Maesbury Marsh. Opened just three months ago, Canal Central is probably the most modern post office in Britain and one of only a handful opened in recent years. Since the start of the decade, the network of 18,500 post offices has been slashed to barely 12,500. A further 3,000 are expected to close within the next 18 months. Against this gloomy background, subpostmaster Iain Campbell, 45, and his partner Fiona MacDonald, 36, decided that they needed to be radical to boost their hopes of survival. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Moston
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyM40 9WJ, EnglandThe shutters are down on several shops in the litter-strewn parade, including the Chain Bar sub-post office, which was axed two years ago as part of the Government\'s \'urban reinvention programme\'. It was closed down despite the fact that Moston in north-east Manchester is home to 20,000 people, many of whom are dependent on state benefits and were regular post office users. As far as the people of Moston are concerned, the programme triggered urban destruction. Baker Nick Cogger, 47, has been in the area for 20 years. He runs Howarth\'s Bakery with his wife Julie, 47. He shakes his head at the terrible state of the area and says: \'We don\'t see many of our customers any more. They drifted away when the post office went.\' Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Sheepy Magna
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyCV9 3QR, EnglandThree thousand have closed since early 2002, largely as a result of the scrapping of old-style benefits books and an urban closure programme. But this number will pale into insignificance compared with the avalanche of closures in coming years as the Government withdraws its Â£150m annual subsidy to rural branches. And the withdrawal of the Post Office card account, confirmed this month, will also hit hard. The four million people who use the account to obtain cash will be forced to have their benefits paid direct into bank accounts. Financial Mail visited three rural post offices to gauge villagers\' reactions to the Government\'s decision: Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Sleights
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyI see on your map that one of several post offices in Whitby is threatened and I am sure it is a valuable local service. But there are a string of villages going W from Whitby up the Esk valley. This is rural terrain with small winding roads and lots of steep hills and travelling around is not easy. In winter roads may be treacherous - hills/ice/drifts (thought not much this winter). In summer there may be "tourist blockages" - especially since the screening of "Heartbeat"! There are buses but infrequent. I live in Sleights - the second village up the valley from Whitby and have signed petition to keep our post office open. It would be a real blow to the community if it closed. Villages further up the valley have much worse communications and would be even more badly affected. So, strength to the campaign. Frank Harwood

properties.name: Tavistock
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyPL19 9JWOn the edge of Dartmoor National Park lies the ancient abbey town of Tavistock. It is the starting point for travelling postmistress Ann Dredge, who sets out three days a week to take a lifeline to 18 isolated communities. Her adapted green Vauxhall van has a Post Office logo with the slogan \'An essential part of everyday life\' emblazoned on its side. Yet only when Ann, 48, cranks a lever to open the rear door, and a glassfronted post office counter appears, is its nature revealed. From the van, Ann hands out benefits, collects payments for utility bills, and sells stamps and stationery. She can also issue foreign currency as well as taking television and road licence payments. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Watford
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyWD18 0EJ, England

properties.name: Watford
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyWD18 0EJ, EnglandThe axe starts to fall on urban post offices this month as bosses begin shutting a fifth of the total 17,500 branches. At Watford, Hertfordshire, half the branches will go. Financial Mail asked customers and postmasters what they think. We also asked Post Office boss David Mills to justify a closure plan that rips the heart out of local communities. Customers waiting their turn at Vicarage Road post office smile wryly at a poster taped to the wall. It promises \'one month for consultation with the community\'. The month is up on February 20. But the shelves have already been emptied, the drinks refrigerator has been disconnected and the front doormat taken away. This tiny branch, close to the home of Watford football club, is among those facing the axe under the Post Office\'s \'urban reinvention programme\'. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Wheatley
properties.description: Posted by Thisismoney

properties.name: Wheatley, Oxon
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyIn March 2003, thousands of readers pledged to join our fight to save Britain\'s post offices, and with the introduction of new payment methods for state pensions and other benefits, more people than ever were voicing their concerns. Neil MacCormack, 45, sub-postmaster at Wheatley in Oxfordshire, says: \'If we do not act now, it will be too late. If this change goes through, it will force post offices out of business and a vital community service will be destroyed for ever. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby \'The vast majority of my customers, most of them pensioners, back the campaign and are refusing to be forced into opting for new payment methods they don\'t want. They will fight to the bitter end.\'

properties.name: Whitby
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyReporter Toby Walne (pictured) travelled on a motorbike from John o\'Groats to Land\'s End to report on the impact of the Government\'s plans to scrap benefits passbooks that give claimants access to cash at post offices, spelling doom for hundreds of the 17,500 branches. On day five he reached the charming town of Whitby... A local newspaper reports that a post office in the town faces the axe. The people who rely on the Fishburn Park post office are furious that their long-established branch will close at the end of the month. There has been no official notification of the closure, but if this was designed to avoid bad publicity, it has failed. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby

properties.name: Youlgreave
properties.description: Posted by ThisismoneyDE45 1UR, EnglandThe post office at the heart of Youlgreave village in the glorious Peak District faces a bleak future with the Government\'s decision to axe the Post Office card account. Three years ago, when pensioners and others on benefits were told they could no longer receive payments in cash, hundreds took the Post Office\'s advice and opened a card account, which allows benefits, pensions and tax credits to be collected at post offices using a card and Pin. They thought that doing so secured the future of their post office branch. But now they fear the worst. If the account is scrapped, as the Government has now indicated it will be, pensioners and other benefits recipients will be forced to use their banks, stripping post offices of business and revenue. Read the full story Blog: Travels with Toby
